channel.title: Building a computer - experiences?
channel.description:
Ok, I was thinkin about building my own desktop soon, and was wondering about theese things:
[b]1:[/b] How long will it take to buld it, when you got all the parts ready?
[b]2:[/b] What can go wrong? Serious answers, no "Aww mah gawd, pleinn laik crozhed ontap of it!" [b] 3:[/b] What are your own experiences? [b] 4:[/b] About price for the parts that will be used to make a good gaming computer. Able to run Crysis.

item.title: Building a computer - experiences?
item.dc:creator: @PeterMan PeterMan
item.description:
@PeterMan wrote:

Thanks everyone

Also 1 question, do anyone know if Newegg ships to Norway or any country in the Europe?

Read full topic

item.title: Building a computer - experiences?
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

It’s piss easy to put it. I built my first computer in 2 ish hours… Just read any thing that came with it if your worried. Oh if you worried your going to fry something, earth your self somehow. I had a problem with a long cable… I mean REALLY LONG. took it down the shed. snipped, stripped and soldered. took 10 mins. Wire problem sorted.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a computer - experiences?
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

[quote=“PeterMan, post:9, topic:253054”][quote author=xEnt link=topic=334291.msg2603059#msg2603059 date=1230369632]

Oh yes, I completely forgot about that. Before you buy anything, try to find a components list and work from that, I found one and had 2 changes before buying anything. I think the only thing I didn’t change was the processor and ram.

Yeah, I kinda got problems figuring if I should pick dual core or quad core, and what graphics card.

4870, if that can suit your budget, or GTX260+ core 216.

As for the CPU, go with a fast duel core (E8500 3.16ghz) or the lowest quad core (Q6600 2.4ghz).

In this current age in gaming, the E8500 will do much better in gaming.
[/quote]
Is it this? http://www.mpx.no/aspx/produkt/prdinfovnet.aspx?plid=90086 Sorry about the Norwegian.
If so, I will buy it from this Norwegian page, short deliverance :P[/quote]
Yes that is the CPU.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a computer - experiences?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

I’ve worked in a computer shop for about a week, for school. All I did was assemble computers.

  1. 2 hours at max
  2. If you take time to think over what you are doing, nothing can go wrong. Just don’t wire things wrong and use the provided guides if you aren’t sure what you are doing.
  3. It’s piss easy.
  4. All I did was assemble pc’s. I got a box with all the parts that were picked by the customers.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a computer - experiences?
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

If your new at building a computer, its going to be all trial and error. Hopfully not getting wrong parts, but reading the manuals for each thing will easily get you sorted.

For a crysis running PC smoothly, you will need around 700$+ USD, and that’s from newegg.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a computer - experiences?
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

PeterMan:

1: How long will it take to buld it, when you got all the parts ready?

Took me about 2-3 hours to build my first pc.

PeterMan:

2: What can go wrong? Serious answers, no “Aww mah gawd, pleinn laik crozhed ontap of it!”

Err, quite a lot of things, but unless you connect the wrong wire to something or forget to plug the fans in, not a lot really.

[quote=“PeterMan, post:1, topic:253054”]
3: What are your own experiences?[/quote]

I had a bit of trouble with some of the wires and the computer fans(case came with fans with wires that were a bit too short), and I also had sore legs, and back etc. I built it on the floor.

[quote=“PeterMan, post:1, topic:253054”]
4: About price for the parts that will be used to make a good gaming computer. Able to run Crysis.[/quote]

It depends where you buy the parts, what parts you need and other things. The PC I built(a few months ago, around March) was around £750 GBP and it plays Crysis reasonably well(all settings on high, 8x anti-aliasing unless it’s the levels with snow, then 4). I’m sure around this time(with christmas sales, etc) you could build a PC that runs Crysis reasonably well for $/£500 odd.

After looking around for similar spec computers, I found it was a good £100-200 cheaper, if you add the cost of a new monitor etc, it’s roughly around the same as a new PC with all the extras. If you think about it though, you built it so you know what everything is, and where it goes, so you can easily upgrade if you ever need to. You can also buy good hardware so you know it’ll last.

I’d say it’s worth it if you want to do it, or save money(because you will if you don’t need to buy anything extra), but if you’re not fussed about either, you should just buy a pre-built one.

Read full topic

I added a new dvd-rom today, that took 5mins…it might take a day or two with all the wires, mother board, casing, cases for the pc, etc,. you save a lot of money though
